Author: LocoMB#8593
Content:
yay! here is some (not so n00b) Question:
I just built komodod from source, have it running, and I can ask it simple Qs via komodo-cli like getwalletinfo and so on - so far so good.
Now to launch Pirate, I sort of understand I have to do stuff like this:
./komodod -ac_name=PIRATE -ac_supply=0 -ac_reward=25600000000 -ac_halving=77777 -ac_private=1 -addnode=136.243.102.225 &
... ‚ùì however, is this really the cmd to hook into the existing Pirate ac, or is it the cmd to launch a complete new ac?
reason why I ask is that it still says  '-ac_halving=77777' but that has changed, hasn't it?

Author: LocoMB#8593
Content:
so this is a squeaky clean and blank new komodod running with KMD:
 ./komodo-cli getwalletinfo
{
  "walletversion": 60000,
  "balance": 0.00000000,
  "unconfirmed_balance": 0.00000000,
  "immature_balance": 0.00000000,
  "txcount": 0,
  "keypoololdest": 1538322777,
  "keypoolsize": 101,
  "paytxfee": 0.00000000
}

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is changed internally the 77777

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so externally nothing changes

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: any change to the accepted command params makes it a new chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it should print the new halving on startup

Author: LocoMB#8593
Content:
ah ok! so if I want to make a Pirate wallet, I use the cmd as in the sticky on top of this channel?
./komodod -ac_name=PIRATE -ac_supply=0 -ac_reward=25600000000 -ac_halving=77777 -ac_private=1 -addnode=136.243.102.225 &

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: yes

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: yes, use *exactly* what the topic has

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content:
While I'm among the first to make pleas for added decentralization, I'm curious (other than smaller pool ops looking to equalize incomes) about the sudden echoing of spreading hash.
@mountaindrifter Besides possible downtime loss and the need for valid failovers, what is it that you see as "better" with more pools?

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: If by "us" you mean pool ops, I could agree; otherwise, I fail to make the connection

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless you have 100% of hashrate, you dont have enough hash to find a block in a minute

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content:
`us being anyone that doesn't command enough hash power to find a block within 1 minute`
Statistically, that's everyone

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: in terms of pools (discounting for ops incomes) 1 pool and 9999 pools aren't going to change the longterm earnings of any miner, be it solo or in the pool

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: I'm not counting for random luck, I mean in the overall terms of x hash will (on average) find y blocks over z time

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: so, I'm still not seeing the connection between more/less pools and solo miners

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: x hash is x hash

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: nor am I seeing the "hurt"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as long as no pool is over 50% and no solo miner is over 50%

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems pretty much equivalent

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but with the big fluctuations happening, it would be better if no pool is close to 50%

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and that is where the "more pools are better" comes from

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: that makes the "hurt" claim all the more confusing üòõ

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: If I purchase the entire 43M available on the 2 main rental sites, how do you see 1 pool or 9999 making any matter?

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: and that 1% isn't going to change no matter how "thin" it's spread

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: for clarity, I wouldn't do that because I'd actually make less than I do now, but that's another topic üòõ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: X amount of hashrate will find the same number of blocks, be it on 1 pool or 1000
